Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Katherine A. Mazzio of the University of Washington to conduct a research project in the Math and Physical Sciences area during the summer of 2013 at Victoria University of Wellington in Wellington, New Zealand. The project title is "Exciton Dissociation in Hybrid Materials for Solar Energy Conversion." The host scientist is Justin Hodgkiss.

One of the most promising renewable resources lies in photovoltaics for electricity generation. For many applications, however, the product output of photovoltaics has been limited by materials scarcity and competition with the microelectronics industry, as well as by a limited ability to control the structure-property relationships of the materials used in photovoltaic devices. Using a recently developed method for the in-situ functionalization of semiconducting nanocrystals with pi-conjugated molecules during growth, the performance of hybrid photovoltaic devices is expected to be significantly enhanced, while allowing them to be solution processed. This project examines the charge transfer dynamics in these new hybrid materials. Specifically, it will investigate how varying the concentration of polythiophene ligands affects both the loading on cadmium selenide quantum dots and the resulting charge transfer rates for use in hybrid photovoltaic devices. This information will result in a better understanding of the charge transfer processes in hybrid materials, while aiding in future design aspects of optoelectronic materials, which will in turn benefit society by resulting in improved materials for photovoltaic devices towards zero-emission electricity generation.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the proposed research will result in the Fellow obtaining a fundamental understanding of the electron transport phenomena inside the active layer of these next-generation solar cells. The Fellow will couple this experimental data with computer modeling of the charge transport processes in order to act as a predictive tool for the rational design of future light-harvesting systems. The results of this project will be published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at international conferences, in addition to informal presentations regarding the EAPSI program and the results obtained over the course of this program within the University of Washington.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alternative energy resources are increasingly becoming viable alternatives for future global energy production as efforts are being put forth to alleviate the use of fossil fuels because of decreased availability and due to a greater understanding of the long-term global effects of CO2 and other greenhouse gas emissions. One of the most promising renewable resources lies in photovoltaics for electricity generation. Hybrid photovoltaics have recently generated interest due to the possibility of compensating for the limitations of purely organic or purely inorganic photovoltaics, including enhancing the short charge carrier lifetime and mobility of the organic materials through inclusion of the inorganic, while simultaneously maintaining the light-weight and solution processability of the organic. This project aimed to develop an understanding of the electronic dynamics of conjugated polymer/nanocrystal hybrid materials for applications in light-weight and flexible electronics. This research is transformative because it will facilitate the design of future high performance materials for hybrid electronics, including photovoltaics and biological labels. This project coupled expertise in the design and synthesis of hybrid electronic materials with expertise in the analysis of the electronic dynamics in materials over a wide range of timescales using a suite of ultrafast laser spectroscopies. These new hybrid materials serve to address the issues of exciton dissociation and active layer morphology in hybrid photovoltaics by directly attaching the electron donor and acceptor materials, and it is necessary to gain a fundamental understanding of the charge transport processes in order to continue to rational design of improved photovoltaic materials in order to advance solar energy conversion technologies.

 

The work done over the course of this project will benefit society by guiding the development of materials for photovoltaic devices towards zero-emission electricity generation. The research involved in this project was highly interdisciplinary, bringing together synthetic chemistry and materials physics in order to address the fundamental societal issue of alternative energy from a materials design perspective. There were direct educational benefits with this project, including providing a graduate student with international mentoring in a laboratory focusing on advanced optical spectroscopies, while also providing exposure to the society, culture, science and science policy of New Zealand. This exposure will contribute to effective communication skills cross-culturally and to broad audiences. The results of this work will be published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at international conferences. Finally, this work is helping to continue a tradition of international collaborative research that is proving to be successful and important in meeting world energy goals.
